[[File:324373390.gif|thumb|Cartoon by [[Carlos Latuff]] for Saudi Arabia's #women2drive Movement]]
â
[[Manal al-Sharif]] is a [[women's rights]] [[activist]] from [[Saudi Arabia]] who helped start a women's right to drive campaign in 2011. A women's rights activist who had previously filmed herself driving, [[Wajeha al-Huwaider]], filmed al-Sharif driving a car<ref name="France24_huwaiderfilmed" /> as part of the campaign. The video was posted on [[YouTube]] and [[Facebook]].<ref name="AP_detained21May" /><ref name="cnn22May_detained" /> Al-Sharif was detained and released on 21 May<ref name="Indep23May_detained" /> and rearrested the following day.<ref name="RTBF_geek" /> On 30 May, al-Sharif was released on [[bail]],<ref name="AFP_Sharif2BFreed30May" /> on the conditions of returning for questioning if requested, not driving and not talking to the media.<ref name="NationalAE_SharifFree30May" /> ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[Associated Press]]'' associated the women's driving campaign with the wider pattern of [[2010â2011 Middle East and North Africa protests|Arab world protests]] and the long duration of al-Sharif's detention with Saudi authorities' fear of protests.<ref name="nyt_reputation" /><ref name="AP_10days_26May" />
+
Manal al-Sharif is a [[women's rights]] [[activist]] from [[Saudi Arabia]] who helped start a women's right to drive campaign in 2011. A women's rights activist who had previously filmed herself driving, [[Wajeha al-Huwaider]], filmed al-Sharif driving a car<ref name="France24_huwaiderfilmed" /> as part of the campaign. The video was posted on [[YouTube]] and [[Facebook]].<ref name="AP_detained21May" /><ref name="cnn22May_detained" /> Al-Sharif was detained and released on 21 May<ref name="Indep23May_detained" /> and rearrested the following day.<ref name="RTBF_geek" /> On 30 May, al-Sharif was released on [[bail]],<ref name="AFP_Sharif2BFreed30May" /> on the conditions of returning for questioning if requested, not driving and not talking to the media.<ref name="NationalAE_SharifFree30May" /> ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[Associated Press]]'' associated the women's driving campaign with the wider pattern of [[2010â2011 Middle East and North Africa protests|Arab world protests]] and the long duration of al-Sharif's detention with Saudi authorities' fear of protests.<ref name="nyt_reputation" /><ref name="AP_10days_26May" />
[[Wajnat Rahbini]], a Saudi actress famous in the Arab world for playing in the satirical comedy ''[[Tash ma Tash]]'', broadcast annually during [[Ramadan]], drove her car "in defiance of a long-standing ban on female driving"<ref name="E247_Rahbini" /> on 4 June in Jeddah. She was detained after exiting her car and released the following day without bail.<ref name="GulfNews_Rahbini" /><ref name="E247_Rahbini" />
[[Wajnat Rahbini]], a Saudi actress famous in the Arab world for playing in the satirical comedy ''[[Tash ma Tash]]'', broadcast annually during [[Ramadan]], drove her car "in defiance of a long-standing ban on female driving"<ref name="E247_Rahbini" /> on 4 June in Jeddah. She was detained after exiting her car and released the following day without bail.<ref name="GulfNews_Rahbini" /><ref name="E247_Rahbini" />
